item.title: 2022 End-of-year Review
item.description: Learnings from 2022 goal-setting. I was inspired to start this whole annual goal-setting thing because of [[Reading List|Atomic Habits]]. Picking 2 goals to focus on is too much.

item.title: 2022 Initial Goal Setting
item.description: What is one habit I hope to establish in 2022? Candidates Sleeping early + getting up early Reading a book a month ==‚úÖ Exercising and/or spending time in nature 140 minutes a week (~20 min/day)== - Chosen!

item.title: 2022 Mid-year Check-in
item.description: Mid-Year Review (5/22/2022) 1. Working Out and/or Spending Time Outdoors 140 min+/week According to Fitness app (data collected from Apple Watch)

item.title: 2023 End-of-year Review
item.description: Learnings from 2023 goal-setting. My goal was to read 12 books in 12 months. According to my [[Reading List]] and GoodReads, I read 18 books in 12 months.

item.title: 2023 Initial Goal Setting
item.description: I want to read a book every month. That’s twelve books in twelve months. The number of books is arbitrary, really.

item.title: 2023 Learnings
item.description: Have confidence in your curiosity and where it will take you. Say no. Set boundaries. Every true “no” is a “yes” to your true self.

item.title: 2023 Mid-year Check-in
item.description: According to my [[Reading List]], I’ve read ten books as I’m writing this (08.21.2023). I may be on track for now, but during the semester I will have less time to read books.

item.title: Deep Work
item.description: Definitions Deep work: Professional activities performed in a state of distraction-free concentration that push your cognitive capabilities to their limit.

item.title: Efficient genome editing in the mouse brain by local delivery of engineered Cas9 RNP complexes
item.description: Link to paper Summary The study demonstrates efficient genome editing in post-mitotic neurons of the adult mouse brain using Cas9 ribonucleoprotein (RNP) complexes -> holds promise for correcting/inactivating genetic causes of neurological diseases characterized by specific neuronal populations via safe Cas9 delivery with minimal immune response Engineered Cas9 variants with multiple SV40 nuclear localization sequences (NLS) enhance the efficiency of neuronal genome editing in vivo by 10x, addressing the challenge of tissue-specific delivery Mouse model Ai9 tdTomato is used to detect Cas9 editing, providing a quantitative method for genome modification.

item.title: Flow Cytometry
item.description: Helpful animated video Takeaways from video Flow cytometry is an experimental technique used to count and analyze individual cells within a mixed population based on their size, shape, and other properties.

item.title: Focus & Hell Yeah or No
item.description: Focus Being in the zone‚Äîaka being in a [[Quotes#Flow by Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi|flow state]]‚Äîis arguably one of the most awesome, fulfilling feelings out there.

item.title: For Blood and Money
item.description: Overview Focuses on the biotech industry, billionaires, and the pursuit of blockbuster drugs. Explores the story of Acerta Pharma, Imbruvica, Calquence, and their role in revolutionizing blood cancer treatment.

item.title: In vivo CRISPR base editing of PCSK9 durably lowers cholesterol in primates
item.description: Link to paper Summary The paper demonstrates the successful in vivo delivery of CRISPR adenine base editors using lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) to modify disease-related genes in cynomolgus monkeys (Macaca fascicularis).

item.title: Man, I'm lucky
item.description: 2023-09-28 For being in the Bay Area, being at UC Berkeley, getting to work with and learn from people I look up to and meet more of them in person!

item.title: My Values
item.description: I’d like to be… Intentional. Have clarity in your values and self-defined purpose. Consistent. Sustained intention. Have a high follow-through rate: if you say you’re going to do something, do it.

item.title: Quotes
item.description: Cool quotes. Gottfried Ephraim Lessing If God were to hold all Truth concealed in his right hand, and in his left only the steady and diligent drive for Truth, albeit with the proviso that I would always and forever err in the process, and to offer me the choice, I would with all humility take the left hand.

item.title: Reading is pretty darn cool
item.description: Reading This story probably sounds familiar to many people. I used to love books as a kid‚ÄîGoosebumps, the Percy Jackson series, you name it‚ÄîI could read for hours on end without needing a break.

item.title: Reading List
item.description: A master list of books / novellas / short stories / essays (1) I want to read, (2) am currently reading, (3) or have read in the past.

item.title: Real talk - interesting conversation questions
item.description: Pull up a random number generator and ask away! Remember to create a safe, non-judgmental space for everyone participating. If you’d like to add to the list, feel free to contact me with suggestions for questions.

item.title: Sequential appetite suppression by oral and visceral feedback to the brainstem
item.description: Link to paper Summary Distinct circuits for short and long timescale control Sequential negative feedback signals from the mouth and gut engage distinct circuits in the caudal brainstem, controlling feedback behavior on both short (PRLH) and long (GCG) timescales PRLH neurons respond to oral cues and control short-term feeding dynamics PRLH neurons in the caudal nucleus of the solitary tract (cNTS) exhibit sustained activation by visceral feedback during stomach nutrient infusion During oral consumption, PRLH neurons shift to a phasic activity pattern linked to the taste of food Optogenetic manipulations show that PRLH neurons regulate the duration of seconds-timescale feeding bursts GCG neurons respond to GI feedback for long-term satiety GCG neurons in the cNTS are activated by mechanical feedback from the gut and track the cumulative amount of food consumed.

item.title: Thoughts in Passing
item.description: For random thoughts that do not warrant standalone pages. I want to come up with a list of questions I can ask myself periodically to orient myself in my personal and professional lives.

item.title: What does success mean to you?
item.description: To my future self, I hope you’re healthy, both physically and mentally. Seriously, health is the number one priority. Lift weights and do some form of cardio, no matter how old you may be.

item.title: What kind of research assistant do I want to be?
item.description: I will… Show up on time. Be consistent and reliable. Take ownership of my work. Be proactive and think about how my job fits into bigger pictures (e.

item.title: Yearly Goals
item.description: The days are long, but the years are short. Think of it as New Year’s resolutions, but with an extra dose of structure.
